channel.title: Stealing Images
channel.description:
http://shopping.forumcommunity.net/?t=10825753
That site has linked to my blog for the background picture. So my bandwidth has srsly shot up over the past few days. I've just emailed asking to take it down, but apparently it's in Italian. Anything else I can do? It's a dick move to directly link to me for my shit, but I still wouldn't exactly like it if they just copied it to their server and used it.

item.title: Stealing Images
item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

This site became a notorious surprise image and Internet meme, and was—and, through external hosting, still is—used regularly for bait-and-switch pranks, preventing hot-linking in a hostile manner, and defacing websites, in order to provoke extreme reactions. Even though the display of the site was removed in 2004, its images are mirrored throughout the Internet today.
The Goatse.cx image is sometimes used by website authors in attempt to get websites to stop hot-linking from them. By replacing the hot-linked image with the embarrassing image the moment hot-linking has been discovered, an unsubtle message would be sent to the offending website's operators, viewable to all who view the web page in question.[23] As an example, in 2007, Wired.com hot-linked to another site in an article about the "sexiest geeks of 2007"; the said site swapped the hot-linked image with one from Goatse.cx.[24] This action is practiced by website owners either because bandwidth is an issue to them, or simply for the enjoyment of pranking.

Images on the site such as hello.jpg and others have become subjects of parodies, mirrors, and tributes.[25]


lolwut
also this is old

Read full topic

[/quote]
But put it in Italian ;)[/quote]

item.title: Stealing Images
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:8, topic:384252”]What kind of (web)server do you run? If it’s apache, this will work:

http://altlab.com/htaccess_tutorial.html
Tells you how to disable hotlinking.

If it’s another one, there is almost surely a way to do the same thing. It basically checks the referrer, and if it’s not your site, you can choose to either serve another image (like ‘Please don’t steal my bandwidth.’), or just not serve an image at all.[/quote]

Apache. I get what that link does, I just didn’t sit down and think about what I could do. My immediate reaction was to send them an email asking them to stop considering it was completely stolen and hotlinked, no one even told me about it.

I went with a little of that but modified it. As you can see on their site now, they had noticed already and there’s a new picture of balloons

Read full topic

item.title: Stealing Images
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

What kind of (web)server do you run? If it’s apache, this will work:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:4, topic:384252”]http://altlab.com/htaccess_tutorial.html
Tells you how to disable hotlinking.[/quote]

If it’s another one, there is almost surely a way to do the same thing. It basically checks the referrer, and if it’s not your site, you can choose to either serve another image (like ‘Please don’t steal my bandwidth.’), or just not serve an image at all.

Read full topic
